claim: France uses the euro as its official currency

supporting.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency in 1999, replacing the French franc, as part of the Eurozone.

attacks.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency in 1999, replacing the French franc, as part of the Eurozone.
Some regions in France, like overseas territories, still use currencies other than the euro.
The adoption of the euro was controversial in France, with significant opposition questioning its economic benefits.
The use of alternative currencies in overseas territories is limited and does not undermine the euro's status as the official currency of mainland France.
Despite initial opposition, the euro has been widely accepted in France, and polls show majority support for its continued use.
The economic stability brought by the euro has been empirically demonstrated, countering claims of its negative impact.

supporting.text: The euro is the only legal tender accepted for transactions in France, as mandated by the European Union for Eurozone members.

attacks.text: The euro is the only legal tender accepted for transactions in France, as mandated by the European Union for Eurozone members.
Certain overseas territories of France, such as French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.

Unofficial acceptance of other currencies does not change the legal tender status of the euro in France.
The peg does not make the CFP franc equivalent to the euro in legal terms, as it remains a distinct currency.

supporting.text: French law explicitly designates the euro as the national currency, with all government transactions conducted in euros.

attacks.text: French law explicitly designates the euro as the national currency, with all government transactions conducted in euros.
Some regions in France, like overseas territories, use other currencies alongside the euro for local transactions.

The use of other currencies in overseas territories is limited and does not negate the euro's status as the official national currency.
The franc is no longer legal tender, and all active financial obligations have been converted to euros by law.
Local businesses in overseas territories often prefer euros for stability, reducing the practical use of alternative currencies.

supporting.text: France does not have any official alternative or parallel currency; the euro is universally used in all financial and economic activities.

attacks.text: France does not have any official alternative or parallel currency; the euro is universally used in all financial and economic activities.
Some regions in France, like overseas territories, use currencies pegged to the euro but not the euro itself.
These territories are not part of metropolitan France and their currency arrangements do not affect the euro's status as the official currency of mainland France.
Historical records show that France used the franc before the euro, and some argue the transition was not fully accepted by all citizens.
Public opinion polls indicate that the majority of French citizens now support the euro as their official currency.
Certain sectors, like black markets or informal economies, may still use alternative currencies or barter systems.
Such activities are illegal and do not constitute an official alternative currency recognized by the French government.

supporting.text: The European Central Bank, which governs the euro, has jurisdiction over monetary policy in France, further confirming the euro's official status.

attacks.text: The European Central Bank, which governs the euro, has jurisdiction over monetary policy in France, further confirming the euro's official status.
Jurisdiction over monetary policy does not necessarily confirm the official status of a currency, as some countries use foreign currencies unofficially.
The European Central Bank's jurisdiction is limited to Eurozone members, but France could theoretically still use another currency if it left the Eurozone.
Historical precedent shows that countries under a central bank's monetary policy consistently use the official currency without exception.
France has no legal mechanism or political will to leave the Eurozone, making the theoretical possibility irrelevant.
Exceptions exist where regions unofficially adopt foreign currencies despite central bank policies, such as dollarization in some economies.
